Sorry.... It seems I looked a wrong line...

I think nova CLI usually provides an option for non-default value, so --delete-on-termination looks fine for nova CLI.

@Akihiro, yes, in OSC, the format is very uniform, the target parameters are explicitly set and then processed in the code logic.
However, I compared the handling of boolean types in novaclinet and OSC, novaclient did not follow this implementation, e.g.[1]. I will follow the previous implementation in novaclient and then update OSC[2], using the implementation in the above documentation. 

How about using "--enable-delete-on-termination" and "--disable-delete-on-termination" in OSC?

[1]https://github.com/openstack/python-novaclient/blob/master/novaclient/v2/shell.py#L3536-L3540
[2]https://review.opendev.org/#/c/673725

> At a second look, this option is proposed to 'server-create'.

I'm not sure why you say that but this is for the nova volume-attach command, not server create (nova boot).

> why not just add action="store_true"

Yeah, this should add action="store_true", while specifying "--delete-on-termination" means "delete-on-termination=True", will be added.

In case of OSC, we usually use --foo and --no-foo for a boolean option. If there is more appropriate and/or natural expression over --no-foo, we use such expression. For example, we use --private over --no-public.

The guideline is explained at OSC document [1].

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/python-openstackclient/latest/contributor/command-options.html#boolean-options

At a second look, this option is proposed to 'server-create'. It is related to a volume, so it is better to include 'volume' keyword in the option name.

"delete" is a verb, so "enable/disable-<verb>" looks tricky a bit.

In addition, "termination" might be replaced with "delete" because we use "nova delete" when deleting a server.

Checking OSD status on a resource constrained node with many OSDs configured can take more than 60s, this means that a global value of 15s is too small.
So, for checking OSDs (or OSDs+MONs) timeout should be 120s and for checking only MONs timeout should be 30s.

tools/airship.message:
Should we add 'trap' to this not to leak a folder each time airship is run?

ENV_FILE=$(mktemp)
trap "{ rm -f $ENV_FILE; }" EXIT
Good catch, will do, thank you.

Is there a reason why we need 'cache'? 
All it looks you could be simply mounting to ${PROMENADE_TMP}:/tmp".
'cache' is hardcoded in promenade source code and we are using it as a shared location for hyperkube binary between init container and main container in promenade pod

To use 'docker cp' we need to create container first anyway. So, 'docker run ... cp' is just one command to do the job. Instead you are proposing to call docker twice: docker create ...; docker cp ... . The only advantage I see is that we will not run container but it's not a big deal to run simple hyperkube container to do one copy operation.
Makes sense, thanks. Then probably we can skip `--net=host`. And may be we could use `cp` command with parameters as entrypoint. Or `docker image save` piped to tar to extract the file.

I would propose to create a main TMP_DIR here and place both env file as well as all other temp files (like PROMENADE_TMP) inside this directory.

That way we don't need to manage multiple trap statements, instead - work with a single directory for all temporary files during the run.

Is elevating the context really necessary? Usually this isn't necessary since we removed low-level DB API checks on having an admin context (many years ago). I guess you're doing this because it's copied from how _reschedule works, but it's probably not necessary.
Yeah, it was copy-paste. Let's drop it.

If this raises AllocationDeleteFailed for some reason we'll stop and the rollback method should cleanup properly. If we reschedule from let's say an RT resize_claim failure on the compute, we'd cleanup the allocations on the instance for the dest node provider here:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/f7f5e1846c7b19aa05817df7f3c4345819db413f/nova/compute/manager.py#L4502

Which is really more like what rollback in this task does (calling revert_allocation_for_migration). Then when rescheduling through conductor we'd hit _preallocate_migration which would swap the allocations again (source node allocations from the instance move to the migration and the alternate host allocations get put on the instance).

Just making sure I'm following the flow here. I see you added a bunch of unit tests but functional tests are really the thing that would be best here since we could assert allocations in placement to make sure things are where we expect them to be. Since this is temporary compat code for Train I won't push for a bunch of complicated functional tests though.

This code only runs for the first schedule of the migration. During reschedule we don't need to add this iteration as it had already an iteration of alternate hosts. 

The only way re-schedule can happen is through calling _execute again. And a re-schedule, as you said, will go through a revert_allocation_for_migration and a preallocate_migration calls. The revert_allocation_for_migration does not care if there is nothing allocated by the instance, it just copies the migration allocation over the instance allocation blindly. So we only need to makes sure that we don't touch the migration allocation here. Then we are safe. I know famous last words. 

I will try to add at least one functional test where this compat code is hit, just for sanity, but covering the whole feels too much for now.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/python-openstackclient/latest/cli/command-objects/floating-ip.html#floating-ip-show

"name or ID" is preferred.

If we go to this route, '_id' suffix will no longer make sense. Perhaps we need to explore how we can accomodate "neutron port" and "L4 port number"...

In case of the neutron API, we accept only ID for a neutron port, but in case of CLI we usually accepts name and ID for almost all resources, so it is natural to support both.

In addition, 'name' support will make scripting easier, as a user  do not need to check UUID for a port (as long as name is unique).

I would like to ask opinions from Dean and Steve.
Yes, it's a bit confusing, but the API is defined like this.
According to the neutron APi reference, this is optional.

I have a concern on too many positional parameters. In OSC convention, we usually have one or two positional parameters and other parameters are --xxxx format (with required=True).

My suggestion is to use positional arguments for one or two important parameters.

I believe this improves the usability. Users do no need to remember the order of arguments.

Would it be more consistent to call this --fixed-ip-address based on the usage in the floating ip create command?  If it is the same thing it should have the same name.

Also put this option next tot he --internal-port and --external-port options so they appear together in help output.
OSC does not necessarily use the names used in the REST API.  Often users do not know or care about the internal names.

nova/compute/manager.py.message: This has to be a kwarg until the compute RPC API major version is incremented in a later release because of you're doing an upgrade and have compute RPC API versions pinned to the older release, the new parameter isn't going to come from the API. You should probably not default this to False either in case the user specified True. You could default to None meaning you don't know since the caller didn't pass it, but that's not very good either. It's probably best to determine from the API if the compute service is new enough to handle this parameter and if not fail in the API with a 409 error.

> You should probably not default this to False either in case 
> the user specified True. You could default to None meaning 
> you don't know since the caller didn't pass it, but that's 
> not very good either. 

In the API, "delete_on_termination" has been processed. Indeed, it is not appropriate to use False or None here. The problem of "delete_on_termination" is not handled here, and this problem is also avoided.

We shouldn't even need this, I remember this coming up in the spec review:

http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/train/approved/support-delete-on-termination-in-server-attach-volume.html#upgrade-impact

"To avoid issues with trying to attach a volume with delete_on_termination=true to a server running on an older compute service, the implementation should just set the field in the API rather than the compute service."

This means that the API can update the BDM with the delete_on_termination value regardless of where the BDM is actually created since it has nothing to do with the compute service. So when you get the volume_bdm back in the API here:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/673133/12/nova/compute/api.py@4023

Just do:

  volume_bdm.delete_on_termination = delete_on_termination
  volume_bdm.save()

It will becomes simple and easy to review.

So if the rebuild fails the vm_state will continue to be ERROR, right ?

For example:

 def wait_for_active():

nova/tests/unit/virt/ironic/test_driver..message: I prefer keeping this test for a case where task_state is not REBUILD_SPAWNING.

Previously, this test wasn't covering the case where task_state = DELETING but now it's not covering the case where task_state != DELETING and vm_state = ERROR.

Actually, test__wait_for_active_abort_deleting on L247 is already covering what you have here, making this duplicate test coverage. So, I think here, you need to change to task_state = None or something else other than DELETING. This will be to cover the case where the spawn fails and the instance is put into ERROR state somehow, and _wait_for_active is supposed to notice and raise InstanceDeployFailure.

I think using task_state=SPAWNING here would work since that's a non-rebuild case and mimics an initial create failure.

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/c92cb75675003d7ae3cbb50959a395862b3cfe18/nova/compute/manager.py#L2242

nova/virt/ironic/driver.py.message:
Reading the description of bug 1455000, it sounds like ERROR was added intentionally in case the spawn fails on the ironic side and you want to delete the instance. So it seems like you'd be re-introducing that problem if you remove this.

If you want to distinguish between when it's OK to wait for ERROR or not, maybe you should check the task_state and if we're rebuilding, then don't check for ERROR?

Sorry I missed this comment here before I added mine.

If it works, I think that checking both task_state and vm_state would be a good to solve this problem. Otherwise I don't see how the driver will figure out if the rebuilding failed (it will probably time out eventually).

author.name: Julia Kreger
author.status: On the moon! With a jetpack!

nova/virt/ironic/driver.py.message: I agree the task state should be checked as well for rebuilds as suggested.

Can you point me to where vm_state is set to ERROR when deployment fails in Ironic? So far, I only see node.provision_state=ironic_states.DEPLOYFAIL

And I can't find the equivalent in libvirt driver which works fine.

How about the following?

```
if (instance.task_state != task_states.REBUILD_SPAWNING and
  (instance.task_state == task_states.DELETING or
  instance.vm_state in (vm_states.ERROR, vm_states.DELETED)))
```

In PS4 and in the other review comments people were talking about checking for task_states.REBUILD_SPAWNING in addition this. Was there any discussion outside this review about why not to do that? Just wondering why it was decided on and then dropped.
I think I had an older version of the change for some reasons. Will restore to previous version.

This is a unfortunate in that we'd have to keep this task_state list in sync with the guards in compute/api if they change, but if the deploy process can put an instance into ERROR state, I see why _wait_for_active needs to abort when it sees ERROR.

I think it's less about the compute API and the fact that during rebuild in the compute, before calling driver.spawn we set the task_state to REBUILD_SPAWNING:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/c92cb75675003d7ae3cbb50959a395862b3cfe18/nova/compute/manager.py#L3056

So this is just here to handle the case that we're rebuilding from ERROR. Yes it's tightly coupled to the task state machine for a rebuild operation, which like you said is unfortunate, but it's also a relatively simple fix.

A comment here would be helpful.
Note to self: this is here to make _wait_for_active raise InstanceDeployFailure if the instance has fallen into ERROR state during the deploy process.

Is is_admin here effectively a system-administrator?
No, it is not. is_admin is the god-mode admin that you would get if you used the admin token set in keystone.conf. It has no scope, and very importantly, all policies are ignored for it.

keystone/common/policies/trust.py.message: So system-admins can no longer cleanup trusts?

nova/exception.py.message:
This is bad for translators. Suggest something more like:

"Machine type X is not compatible with image Y (Z): %(reason)s"

> something doesn't feel quite right with
 > the word "compatible"

"valid" would be fine too. Or s/is not \w+/conflicts/. Whatevs.
Yeah, makes sense.  (Also something doesn't feel quite right with the word "compatible", but I can't think of any better; so I'm fine sticking with it.)
wouldn't be crazy to make this a subclass of FlavorImageConflict
if this was a subclass of FlavorImageConflict

I mentioned this before, but is there a reason we shouldn't make this a subclass of FlavorImageConflict?

As currently worded, that doesn't gel; but as used, it does.
I can buy this argument, thanks for indulging me and explaining it.

Consider this case:

- The image has hw_mem_encryption=True and hw_firmware_type=uefi but no hw_machine_type.
- The SEV compute host has CONF.libvirt.hw_machine_type set to 'x86_64=pc'.

In that case, the conflict has nothing whatsoever to do with the flavor.  So making it a subclass of FlavorImageConflict doesn't feel right to me.  The real conflict is between the request for SEV (wherever it came from), and the calculated machine type (wherever it came from).  That may or may not involve flavors.

In fact it even may or may not involve images: imagine where the flavor has hw:mem_encryption=True and the image only has hw_firmware_type=uefi.  In that case the conflict is nothing to do with the image.

Granted, there's an argument that the *absence* of hw_machine_type on the image is part of the conflict.  But in the first case I gave, this still doesn't involve flavors at all.

BTW I didn't make the exception SEV-specific because I figured there might be other unrelated occasions in the future where a certain machine type (or lack thereof) causes a conflict.  Maybe Kashyap can anticipate such potential scenarios.

  check_str='(role:reader and system_scope:all) or rule:owner',
  scope_types=['system', 'project'],

This would prevent users with the `admin` role on any project from being able to see deployment sensitive information.

  scope_types=['system'],

Eventually, when we go through this for more of the API, operators can flip the config for oslo.policy to reject requests that were made with the wrong scope (e.g., a project administrator attempting to call this API).
